title: Iconic natural history museum exhibit restored, reinterpreted, redisplayed
text:
Iconic natural history museum exhibit restored, reinterpreted, redisplayed January 25, 2017 6:45 PM Rebecca Droke/Post-Gazette Abigail Beddal, a fabricator and shop manager, works to clear debris from the lion in the "Lion Attacking a Dromedary" diorama at the Carnegie Museum of Natural History in Oakland on Tuesday. The diorama, one of the most famous and enduring objects at the museum, was created in 1867 by French naturalist and taxidermist Edouard Verreaux. In 1896, the Carnegie museum acquired from the American Museum of Natural History in New York for $50. Rebecca Droke/Post-Gazette Conservator Gretchen Anderson cleans debris from camel's mouth in the "Lion Attacking a Dromedary" diorama at the Carnegie Museum of Natural History in Oakland. Rebecca Droke/Post-Gazette The head of the courier in the "Lion Attacking a Dromedary" diorama will be one of the last pieces to be reinstalled after it is moved to its final location in the main hallway at the Carnegie Museum of Natural History in Oakland. Conservators discovered -- after doing CT and X-Rays of the 150-year-old diorama -- that the head was constructed from a human skull including teeth. Rebecca Droke/Post-Gazette From left: Marty Elm, Linsly Church and Abigail Beddall remove wood trusses used to support the diorama "Lion Attacking a Dromedary" as it is moved to its new location in the main hallway of at the Carnegie Museum of Natural History in Oakland. Rebecca Droke/Post-Gazette Foreground from left: Lou Renda, Marty Elm and conservator Gretchen Anderson and, back right, Ruth Fauman-Fichman work to unpack and clean the "Lion Attacking a Dromedary." Rebecca Droke/Post-Gazette Abigail Beddall, left, Lou Renda, back right, and Gretchen Anderson work to unpack the "Lion Attacking a Dromedary" diorama at the Carnegie Museum of Natural History in Oakland. Rebecca Droke/Post-Gazette Conservator Gretchen Anderson searches her travel box for an object she needs to clean the "Lion Attacking a Dromedary" diorama at the Carnegie Museum of Natural History in Oakland. Rebecca Droke/Post-Gazette From left: Linsly Church, a conservation tech, conservator Gretchen Anderson, and docent/volunteer Ruth Fauman-Fichman work to figure out how to drape the cape worn by the courier in the "Lion Attacking a Dromedary" diorama. Rebecca Droke/Post-Gazette Conservator Gretchen Anderson cleans debris from the lion in the "Lion Attacking a Dromedary" diorama at the Carnegie Museum of Natural History in Oakland. By Michael A. Fuoco / Pittsburgh Post-Gazette 
With every new glance, the enduring desert drama begins anew. 
The ferocity of the lunging male Barbary lion in mid-attack. The assaulted camel, its leg clawed and bloodied, bellowing in pain and terror. The fear and fight of the sabre-wielding, North African courier atop the dromedary. And all of that violence juxtaposed by the silent stillness of a female lion, fatally felled. 
For more than a century, the striking tableau depicted in the diorama “Lion Attacking a Dromedary” has intrigued, captivated and enthralled visitors at the Carnegie Museum of Natural History. 
Why has this iconic exhibit so fascinated and stirred the imagination of everyone who gazes upon it? Is it the primal story of man vs. beast? Is it that the story’s ending is unknown? Is it the intensity of the action and sounds conjured by a creation that is motionless and mute? Is it all of that and more? 
Whatever it is, generations of Pittsburghers and other visitors to the museum have been so enamored of the diorama, known until this year as “Arab Courier Attacked by Lions,” that it is the museum’s most beloved and famous exhibit next to Dippy, its huge Diplodocus dinosaur. 
Given that, and the 150-year anniversary of the exhibit’s creation by French naturalist and taxidermist Edouard Verreaux for the Paris Exposition of 1867, the diorama has been researched, restored, reinterpreted and relocated to a new display in a more prominent location — the first-floor foyer shared by the Carnegie Museums of Art and Natural History near the Carriage Drive entrance. It had previously been displayed on the second floor near the African Wildlife Hall. 
The new title for the diorama is a translation of its original French name, Lion Attaquant un Dromadaire . 
The redisplayed, restored and reinterpreted exhibit will be unveiled Saturday at noon during a free, daylong symposium sponsored by the museum and the University of Pittsburgh. Scholars and staff from the Carnegie Museums of Natural History and Art and from Pitt will discuss the historical and intellectual contexts of the piece in the morning and the museum process for reinterpretation and reinstallation in the afternoon. 
Registration for the symposium, which includes free museum admission, can be made here . 
Eric Dorfman, the natural history museum director, said it is fitting and symbolic to move and redisplay such an important piece at the intersection of the Museums of Art and Natural History. 
“It’s as much a 19th century piece of art as it is a piece of natural history,” said Mr. Dorfman, who holds a Ph.D. in ecology. “Why not put it in a place where more people can come and engage with it? 
“I have grandparents telling me they looked at the object when they were tiny children. It’s very special to Pittsburgh, very exciting. To me, bringing out stories and making it more prominent is exactly the thing we are trying to do throughout the Museum of Natural History.” 
And, boy, does this natural history/taxidermy art exhibit have stories to tell, with more and more uncovered as research continues on a piece that excites and intrigues museum scholars as much as museumgoers. 
Take, for example, the recent discovery via a CT scan that the courier’s head contains an entire human skull. Museum officials had known for years that human teeth were in the courier’s mouth but did not know about the skull. For decades, an urban legend circulated about other human remains in the mannequin. 
X-rays of the entire exhibit using new technology provided by the Allegheny County Medical Examiner’s office showed there are no other human remains in the mannequin but bones are present in the animals, whose skins are real. The Barbary lion is now extinct. 
As for the human skull, Erin Peters, the museum’s assistant curator of science and research, said that normally the museum would discuss repatriation, or returning human remains to their native land, but there is no way to document where it is from. 
Moreover, Gretchen E. Anderson, who heads the museum’s conservation section, said removing the skull would destroy the mannequin’s head because it is sculpted directly to it. 
Ms. Peters, who holds a Ph.D. in art history and also is a Pitt lecturer in History of Art and Architecture, said her research discovered a stereoscopic image of the exhibit from the Paris exhibition, where it was considered a masterwork, as it is today. The image shows the rider in a more upright, commanding position than its current position of being slumped over in the saddle. Why and where this was done is unknown. 
The photograph also provided proper credit for the diorama to Edouard Verreaux instead of his brother, Jules, also a taxidermist. For more than a century, the museum believed Jules Verreaux had created the piece. 
Two years after the Paris Exposition, the piece was purchased by the American Museum of Natural History in New York where it remained in storage for three decades. The museum came to believe the piece too theatrical, too gauche, and thus not scientifically worthy of museum display. 
In 1896, two years after it opened, the Carnegie Museum of Pittsburgh purchased it for only $50 — and had to pay $45 to have it shipped by rail here where it has been displayed ever since. 
Ms. Peters said new labeling for the exhibit — as well as discussions during the symposium Saturday — will provide insight into the exhibit’s depiction of the courier in the context of 1867 Parisian interpretation of North African culture. Its artistic style was typical in the late 19th century but is now viewed as a stereotyped, colonialist misrepresentation of North Africa and the Middle East. 
The symposium will culminate with a response and community discussion led by the outreach coordinator for the Muslim Association of Greater Pittsburgh.
